papers.title: Modern code review: A case study at Google
papers.authors: Sadowski, C., Söderberg, E., et al.
papers.relevance: Large-scale study showing how review processes self-regulate contribution inflow

semantic_scholar_match.title: Modern Code Review: A Case Study at Google
semantic_scholar_match.abstract: Employing lightweight, tool-based code review of code changes (aka modern code review) has become the norm for a wide variety of open-source and industrial systems. In this paper, we make an exploratory investigation of modern code review at Google. Google introduced code review early on and evolved it over the years; our study sheds light on why Google introduced this practice and analyzes its current status, after the process has been refined through decades of code changes and millions of code reviews. By means of 12 interviews, a survey with 44 respondents, and the analysis of review logs for 9 million reviewed changes, we investigate motivations behind code review at Google, current practices, and developers' satisfaction and challenges.
semantic_scholar_match.venue: 2018 IEEE/ACM 40th International Conference on Software Engineering: Software Engineering in Practice Track (ICSE-SEIP)

citations.reasoning: Research on code review processes consistently shows self-regulating effects on contributions.
